conclusion: Determine the time it takes for light to travel from point O to the AB boundary of the transparent body ABDE.
The refractive index of the material is given as √2.
The angle between the light ray and the normal at point O is 45°.
The light travels a distance equal to the hypotenuse of a right triangle where the other two sides are both equal to the distance OA.
Denote the distance OA as d.
The distance OB can be found using the geometry of the trapezoid.
The light will undergo refraction when it reaches the boundary AB.
The distance AB is simply the horizontal distance d.
Use Snell's law to find the actual path length.
Snell's law: n1 sin θ1 = n2 sin θ2.
n1 is the refractive index of air (approximately 1), n2 is the refractive index of the material (√2), θ1 is the angle of incidence, and θ2 is the angle of refraction.
Given θ1 = 45°, solve for θ2 using Snell's law.
The path length L is the hypotenuse of a right triangle where one angle is 30° and the other angle is 60°.
The hypotenuse L = 2d/√3.
The speed of light in the material is v = c/n.
The time t taken to travel the distance L is t = L/v.
Express time in terms of d: t ≈ 5.45 × 10^-9 d.
The time taken for light to travel from point O to the AB boundary is approximately 5.45 × 10^-9 d.
